Um helium can't be a hydraulic fluid as it is compressible. The term Hydraulic refers to any non-compressible media.  The system is pressurized by helium. The downside to open loop is limited supply of fluid. This is NEVER used in aviation and industry as you sht out all the low pressure side into the atmosphere.  The upside is system weight savings. Which means you might have lots of pressure in the system left but run out of actuation fluid.  This failure is also unpredictable (what state the fins would be in when the pressure stops). What happened during the Falcon 9 failure is a non-redundant system that is "cold pressurized" means the more you use the colder the fluid will become as it is recovered and re-used. They either had ice contamination lock up the actuator/valve or the fluid simply became too cold and lost viscosity.  Because synthetic fluid freezes at about -57 degrees my bet is on ice contamination. Irresponsible to build a spacecraft without at least dual control systems.

But seriously, in aviation design engineers are always looking for single point failure issues.  A process called msg3 is usually performed to find these and determine the domino failure effects.  Since this system is critical to the booster recovery and proper landing it should of had at least 1 backup system.  If this had not been a water landing they would have lost it to the crashing when it flopped over on ground.   A second hydraulic system backup less costly than losing the entire booster

This is why private space launches/missions (compared with those operated by quasi-governmental agencies such as NASA, ESA, JAXA) can become so prohibitively expensive for the entrepreneur/investor: multiple redundancy. And such redundancy expands exponentially with the potential for Human Space Flight operations. There are many ways to save money and do things cheaper with private launches/missions. But omitting redundancy is not one of them. It's axiomatic that parts will fail and malfunction. And very likely that such failures occur will at critical times. Redundancy is insurance. There were still some abnormalities to the flight that no one has pointed out.. The flame moving up one of the landing legs while it was launching, and the oxygen being vented out of the cowling of the second stage engine.. If the engines weren't burning right that'd make it have less thrust, which would require a longer burn to reach separation altitude, which in turn would make it lighter than usual on reentry. I think it ended up too light and the center of thrust vs center of gravity was off kilter and that's why it got unstable. Add to that that it seemed like the reentry burn was much higher throttle than usual (the flame plume was much larger than usual) that'd make it use even more fuel and weigh even less. Plus at one point you see them using the CGT's to try to correct it as it spins and suddenly they aren't working anymore... which to me says they ran out of cold gas which would further offset the balance and cause it to lose further stability.

A bit of nostalgia. Remember when NASA launched a rocket and invited hundreds of people to watch, mostly members of the press a few years after Sputnik? The rocket ignited at the Cape and went a few feet into the air before falling back and exploding. The little radio transmitter in the tip of the rocket was tuned to the loudspeaker system so all the newscasters could hear the "beep, beep, beep" after it landed in the swamp on the Cape.
Dorothy Kilgallen, a famous journalist and a panel member of the1960s TV game show "What's my line" was a witness to the explosion. After hearing the constant "beep, beep, beep" of the satellite sitting somewhere in the swamp said, "Why doesn't somebody go out there, find it and kill it"?
I always thought she had a good sense of humor in "What's my line". You can still see famous people for the first time being introduced to the panel members, like Chuck Yeager and William Shatner being questioned during the show on YouTube. Source: Rocket Men, by Craig Nelson.

In the video you day the hydraulic pump uses helium as its fluid and that it is dumped overboard. That would not work since helium is compressible. From what has previously been said by SpaceX the hydraulic fluid is RP1 from a small tank in the interstage. After the RP1 is used, since its an open loop, it gets dumped back into the main RP1 tank to be used as landing fuel.  I'd not heard that they converted to a closed loop. Also i've never seen anything definitive as to what powers the hydraulic pump, that may well be what the helium is used for. But the helium is not used as the hydralic fluid since hydraulic fluid needs to be non-compressable.

When are we expected to run out of helium?

The hydraulic fluid is not helium, it's an oil. In the open-loop systems it was just a tank of oil, which was pressurized by high pressure helium. The problem with that is once you use the oil to move the fin actuators, it's now at a lower pressure, and there's no way to get it back in the tank to be reused. Fluid under pressure always flows down the pressure gradient, and the only way to get further down the gradient was to dump it.

With the pumped system, they can close the loop. The low pressure used oil is fed back to the pump inlet, and the pump re-pressurizes it, and sends it back to the actuators. There's still a tank (or several tanks, as each fin probably has it's own accumulators), but no helium. This way, they can't run out of oil, but if the system springs a leak, or the pump stops working, you lose all control of the fins.

6:50 You say "the grid fins are actually there to steer it that last little bit and dogleg over to the landing pad".

I really doubt that "the grid fins are actually there..." for the last few seconds of landing. Seems like the grid fins would have little authority at the low airspeeds present at landing. The fact that the booster stabilized via engine gimbaling and made a soft landing, with malfunctioning grid fins (and on target), is evidence that engine gimbaling is the dominant steering force at low airspeeds. I think the grid fins are most effective between the re-entry burn and the landing burn where the airspeed is very high, that's why "the grid fins are actually there".

Something you see in a LOT of rocket failures from the past is when they start tumbling. The aerodynamic stress along either the x or y axis is just too much structurally and they break apart in violent explosions, or they get flight terminated for the same reason. But with the grid-fins, even malfunctioning grid-fins, they keep the rocket from tumbling by providing that drag at the +z end of the rocket. So while it was spinning, the fins were keeping it upright so it didn't tumble. This allowed the rest of the system, the nitrogen thrusters and merlin engine, to try and correct the issue, and they basically succeeded. It was a little worrying seeing it start to precess a bit as that could cause enough torque along the x or y axis to break apart, but the rocket corrected that motion very quickly.

I have to hand it to the structural engineers for building an incredibly tough rocket, and to the software teams who wrote the flight control software so well that it was able to pull off this soft landing and basically save the stage. This was utterly fascinating to watch happen today and I can't wait to hear more about the state the stage is in.

Another thing, with so many launches a year, SpaceX can get in the same number of launches in 1 year that the Shuttle would take 4 years to do, so SpaceX can encounter and rapidly iterate for problems where other launch platforms can't. Also getting the vehicle back let's them autopsy them and see exactly how well they handle things.

Great video, but the statement that this failure is good for future human flight missions is quite a stretch. As Elon Musk mentions in his tweet, the pump is single string (no redundancy) because it is not mission critical. However when people are on board it would become mission critical and hence require redundancy independant of this failure. Human space flight even tends to be double redudant (with the exception of the thermal components and the structure). However, I do agree that there are positives to experiencing failures when the stakes are low.
